text:
CONTENT STANDARD 1. NUMBER OPERATIONS AND CONCEPTS
Students use numbers, number sense, and number relationships in a problem-solving situation.

children.text: Students read and represent numbers up to 9.
Students recognize the larger of two sets. (Which set has more or less?)
Students recognize and name penny, nickel, dime, and quarter using real coins.
Students count with understanding up to 21 objects to solve problems.
Students act out or use objects as strategies to solve problems.
Students use the concept of place value to read and represent numbers up to 99.
Students use sets of objects to compare values and order numerals.
Students use coins (penny, nickel, dime, and quarter) to compare values (more/less).
Students demonstrate computational fluency with basic facts (add to 10).
Students make a picture or use objects as strategies to solve problems.
Students communicate their choice of appropriate grade level procedures and results when performing operations in a problem-solving situation.
Students use the concept of place value to read and write designated numbers up to 999.
Students compare and order whole numbers up to 999.
Students use coins to compare the values and make combinations up to one dollar.
Students demonstrate computational fluency with basic facts (add to 20, subtract from 10).
Students use mental math (fact families) and estimation strategies (referent to a group of 10) to solve problems.
Students look for patterns and use guess and check as strategies to solve problems.
Students communicate their choice of appropriate grade level procedures and results when performing operations in a problem-solving situation.
Students use the concept of place value to read and write designated numbers up to 9,999.
Students compare and order whole numbers up to 9,999.
Students use coins and bills to compare the values and make combinations up to five dollars.
Students demonstrate computational fluency with basic facts (add to 20 and subtract from 20).
Students add and subtract two- and three-digit numbers with and without regrouping.
Students make an organized list and break problems into parts as strategies to solve problems.
Students use estimation strategies (rounding to the nearest 10 or 100, or front-end loading) to solve problems.
Students communicate their choice of procedures and results when performing number operations in a problem-solving situation.
Students use the concept of place value to read and write whole numbers up to 999,999 in words, standard, and expanded form.
Students compare and order whole numbers.
Students use coins and bills to compare the values, make combinations up to $10.00, and make change from amounts up to $5.00.
Students demonstrate computational fluency with basic facts (add to 20, subtract from 20, multiply by 0-10).
Students add and subtract to thousands and multiply hundreds by a single digit.
Students explain their choice of problem-solving strategies and justify their results when performing whole number operations in problem-solving situations.
Students recognize commonly used fractions (halves, thirds, fourths) as parts of a whole using an area model.
Students use estimation strategies to solve problems.
Students use the concept of place value to read and write whole numbers (in words, standard, and expanded form) and decimals (10ths and 100ths).
Students demonstrate computational fluency with basic facts for all four operations, including identifying multiples and factors of designated numbers up to 100.

Students demonstrate an understanding of whole number operations by:
  • explaining the relationships between the operations of addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division; and
  • multiplying by two-digit whole numbers and dividing by single-digit whole numbers.
Students explain their choice of estimation or problem-solving strategies and justify results when performing number operations in problem-solving situations.
Students add and subtract decimals to hundredths and solve problems in the context of money.
Students demonstrate an understanding of fractions as parts of wholes.
Students order, compare, add, and subtract fractions with like denominators.
Students use the concept of place value to read and write decimals (to 1000ths) in words, standard, and expanded form.
Students multiply decimals (10ths & 100ths) and divide whole numbers by 2-digit divisors and divide decimals by whole numbers.
Students represent the number line using integers.
Students explain their choice of estimation and problem solving strategies and justify results when performing number operations with fractions and decimals in problem-solving situations.
Students identify prime and composite numbers and apply prime factorization to numbers less than 100.

Students demonstrate an understanding of fractions and decimals by:
  • representing fractions as division of whole numbers;
  • converting between mixed numbers and improper fractions;
  • simplifying fractions and mixed numbers;
  • writing fractions in equivalent forms;
  • using parts of a set;
  • rounding decimal numbers to 10ths, 100ths, and whole numbers (units) place; and
  • converting between decimals (from .01 to .99), fractions and representing percentages.
Students add and subtract mixed numbers with like denominators.
Students represent repeated multiplication in exponential form.
Students represent and order rational numbers that are greater than or equal to 0 in a variety of equivalent forms in problem-solving situations.
Students use basic operations with integers in problem-solving situations.
Students divide decimal numbers by decimal numbers.

Students explain their choice of estimation and problem- solving strategies and justify results when performing number operations with fractions and decimals in problem-solving situations appropriate to grade level. Students add and subtract fractions and mixed numbers.
Students multiply and divide fractions and mixed numbers.
Students evaluate whole numbers expressed in exponential form.
Students apply the order of operations (whole numbers including grouping symbols and operations, excluding roots and powers) in problem-solving situations.

Students represent and apply numbers in a variety of equivalent forms (such as changing from percent to decimal to fraction, etc.) and in a problem-solving context:
  • prime factors, factors, and multiples;
  • rational numbers and proportions; and
  • square roots and powers.

Students extend understanding and use of basic arithmetic operations on rational numbers.
  • Simplify numerical expressions using the order of operations;
  • Order rational numbers expressed in a variety of forms
Students explain their choice of estimation and problem- solving strategies and justify results of solutions in problem-solving situations involving rational numbers.
Students understand properties of operations with rational numbers.
Students represent and apply real numbers in a variety of forms.
Students apply the structure and properties of the real number system.
Students explain their choice of estimation and problem solving strategies and justify results of solutions in problem-solving situations involving real numbers.
Students use proportional reasoning to solve problems.

text:
CONTENT STANDARD 2. GEOMETRY
Students apply geometric concepts, properties, and relationships in a problem-solving situation.

children.text: Students recognize, name, compare, and sort geometric shapes (circle, square, triangle and rectangle).
Students select, use, and communicate organizational methods in a problem -solving situation using geometric shapes.
Students recognize, name, compare, and sort 2- and 3-dimensional geometric objects.
Students select, use, and communicate organizational methods in a problem-solving situation using 2- and 3- dimensional geometric objects.
Students name, classify, and describe 2- and 3-dimensional geometric objects.
Students identify lines of symmetry in various geometric objects.
Students select, use, and communicate organizational methods in problem- solving situations with 2- and 3- dimensional objects.
Students recognize, name, compare, and sort 2- and 3-dimensional geometric objects.
Students describe and compare various geometric objects using congruency and lines of symmetry.
Students select, use, and communicate organizational methods in a problem-solving situation using 2- and 3- dimensional geometric objects.
Students classify and describe 2- and 3- dimensional geometric objects by their attributes (sides, edges, vertices, and faces).
Students understand the images resulting from reflections (flips).
Students select, use, and communicate organizational methods in problem-solving situations appropriate to grade level.
Students know characteristics of lines (parallel, perpendicular, and intersecting).
Students describe, draw, and classify two-dimensional geometric figures such as triangles, quadrilaterals, and circles.
Students describe, identify, and classify three-dimensional geometric figures such as cylinders, cones, pyramids, rectangular prisms, and spheres.
Students describe and compare various geometric objects using congruency and lines of symmetry appropriate to grade level.
Students select, use, and communicate organizational methods in problem-solving situations appropriate to grade level.
Students classify, describe, compare, and draw representations of 1- and 2- dimensional objects and angles.
Students identify and classify congruent objects by properties appropriate to grade level.
Students communicate the reasoning used in identifying geometric relationships in problem-solving situations appropriate to grade level.

Students classify and describe one- and two-dimensional geometric objects, including:
  • lines, rays, segments, and angles;
  • parallel and perpendicular relationships; and
  • regular polygon types.
Students make conjectures about geometric figures based on knowledge of congruence and similarity.
Students communicate the reasoning used in identifying geometric relationships in problem-solving situations appropriate to grade level.

Students classify and describe one-, two-, and three-dimensional geometric objects, including:
  • lines, rays, segments, and angles;
  • parallel and perpendicular relationships;
  • circles and spheres;
  • regular polygon types;
  • right prisms, cylinders, cones, and pyramids.
Students make conjectures about geometric objects based on knowledge of geometric transformations, congruence, and similarity.
Students use geometric formulas including the Pythagorean Theorem.
Students communicate the reasoning used in identifying geometric relationships in problem-solving situations appropriate to grade level.
Students represent geometric figures using a rectangular coordinate plane.
Students use transformations, congruency, symmetry, similarity, perpendicularity, parallelism, and the Pythagorean Theorem to solve problems.

Students communicate, using mathematical language, to:
  • Interpret, represent, or create geometric figures;
  • Draw or build figures from a mathematical description;
  • Analyze properties and determine attributes of 2- and 3- dimensional objects.
Students communicate the reasoning used in identifying geometric relationships in problem-solving situations.
Students solve problems involving the coordinate plane such as the distance between two points, the midpoint, and slope.
Students connect geometry with other mathematical topics.

text:
CONTENT STANDARD 3. MEASUREMENT
Students use a variety of tools and techniques of measurement in a problem-solving situation.

children.text: Students apply estimation and measurement of length to content problems using non-standard units up to 9 units.
Students apply estimation and measurement of length to content problems using non-standard units up to 99 units.
Students apply estimation and measurement of capacity to content problems using non-standard units.
Students tell time, using both analog and digital clocks to the nearest half-hour.
Students apply estimation and measurement of length to content problems using standard units to the nearest inch.
Students apply estimation and measurement of weight to content problems using non-standards units.
Students tell time, using both analog and digital clocks to the nearest five minutes.
Students apply estimation and measurement of length to content problems using actual measuring devices and express the results in U.S. customary units (inches, feet, and yards).
Students apply estimation and measurement of capacity in problem-solving situations using actual measuring devices and express the results in U.S. customary units (cups, quarts, and gallons).
Students demonstrate relationships within the U.S. customary units in problem- solving situations.
Students determine perimeter of rectangles and squares using models in problem solving situations.
Students tell time, using both analog and digital clocks, to the nearest minute using A.M. and P.M.

Students select and apply appropriate U.S. customary units (half inch, quarter inch, feet, and yards) to the estimation and measurement of length in real-world problems using actual measuring devices.
Students select and apply appropriate U.S. customary units (ounces and pounds) to the estimation and measurement of weight in real-world problems using actual measuring devices.

Students select and apply appropriate U.S. customary units (teaspoons, tablespoons, cups, pints, quarts, and gallons) to the estimation and measurement of capacity in real-world problems using actual measuring devices.
Students demonstrate relationships within the U.S. customary system, given an equivalence chart, in problem-solving situations.
Students determine area and perimeter of rectangles and squares using models in problem-solving situations.

Students use time, in problem-solving situations to:
  • compare relationships among seconds, minutes, and hours;
  • use elapsed time to the nearest minute.

Students apply estimation and measurement of length to content problems using actual measuring devices and express the results in U.S. customary units (parts of inch-halves/fourths, eights inches, feet, yards, and miles).
Students apply estimation and measurement of weight to content problems using actual measuring devices and express the results in U.S. customary units (ounces and pounds).

Students apply estimation and measurement of capacity in real-world problem-solving situations using actual measuring devices and express the results in U.S. customary units (teaspoons, tablespoons, cups, pints, quarts, and gallons).
Students demonstrate relationships within the U.S. customary units, given an equivalence chart, in problem-solving situations appropriate to grade level.
Students determine area and perimeter of triangles, rectangles, and squares using models in problem-solving situations using appropriate units.

Students use time, in problem-solving situations to:
  • compare relationships among seconds, minutes, hours, and days, and
  • use elapsed time to the nearest minute.
Students apply estimation and measurement of length to content problems and express the results in metric units (centimeters and meters).
Students apply estimation and measurement of weight to content problems and express the results in U.S. customary units (ounces, pounds, and tons).
Students apply estimation and measurement of capacity to content problems and express the results in U.S. customary units (teaspoons, tablespoons, cups, pints, quarts, gallons).
Students demonstrate relationships within the U.S. customary units for weight and capacity and within the metric system (centimeters to meters) in problem-solving situations.
Students determine the area and perimeter of regular polygons and the area of parallelograms, with and without models.
Students apply estimation and measurement of length to content problems and convert within the U.S. customary (in, ft, yd, mi) and within the metric system (mm, cm, m, km).
Students apply estimation and measurement of weight to content problems expressing the results in metric units (g, kg).
Students apply estimation and measurement of capacity to content problems expressing the results in metric units (liters).
Students determine the circumference of a circle using models.
Students calculate the areas of triangles and trapezoids.
Students measure angles with a protractor.
Students apply estimation and measurement of weight/mass to content problems and convert within U.S. customary and within metric units (mg, g, kg).
Students apply estimation and measurement of capacity/volume to content problems and convert within metric units (ml, l).
Students select and use the appropriate methods, tools, and units to solve problems involving angle measure, perimeter, circumference, area (including circles), and volume of rectangular solids.
Students apply estimation and measurement using the appropriate methods and units to solve problems involving length, weight/mass, area, surface area, volume, and angle measure.
Students demonstrate an understanding of both metric and U. S. customary systems. Students are able to convert within each system.
Students identify and apply scale, ratios, and proportions in solving measurement problems.
Students solve problems of angle measure including those involving polygons or parallel lines cut by a transversal.
Students solve indirect measurement problems.

text:
CONTENT STANDARD 4. ALGEBRA
Students use algebraic methods to investigate, model, and interpret patterns and functions involving numbers, shapes, data, and graphs in a problem-solving situation.

children.text: Students recognize, describe, and create three-element patterns by using manipulatives.
Students recognize, create, and describe four-element patterns by using manipulatives and graphic representations.
Students apply knowledge of repeating patterns when solving problems.
Students recognize, describe, create, and extend patterns by using manipulatives and graphic representations.
Students apply knowledge of appropriate grade-level patterns when solving problems.
Students recognize, describe, create, and extend patterns by using manipulatives, numbers, and graphic representations.
Students apply knowledge of appropriate grade level patterns when solving problems.
Students recognize, describe, extend, create, and generalize patterns by using manipulatives, numbers, and graphic representations.
Students apply knowledge of appropriate grade level patterns when solving problems.
Students explain a rule given a pattern or sequence.
Students recognize, describe, extend, create, and generalize patterns by using manipulatives, numbers, and graphic representations, including charts and graphs.
Students apply knowledge of patterns when solving problems appropriate to grade level.
Students represent the idea of a variable as an unknown quantity, a letter, or a symbol within addition and subtraction sentences using whole numbers.
Students recognize, describe, extend, create, and generalize patterns, such as numeric sequences, by using manipulatives, numbers, graphic representations, including charts and graphs.
Students apply their knowledge of patterns to describe a constant rate of change when solving problems.
Students represent the idea of a variable as an unknown quantity, a letter, or a symbol within any whole number operation.
Students translate word phrases, which involve addition and subtraction, into mathematical expressions.
Students solve one-step linear equations.
Students evaluate algebraic expressions and formulas, using order of operations, given positive integer values for variables.
Students understand and use basic concepts of the coordinate system, including plotting points in all four quadrants.
Students translate word phrases, which involve the four basic operations to mathematical expressions.
Students solve one- and two- step linear equations each with an integer coefficient and integer solutions.
Students evaluate algebraic expressions and formulas given integer values for variables.
Using simple linear equations, students create a table, and graph the solutions on the coordinate system.
Students use algebraic concepts, symbols, and skills to represent and solve real-world problems.
Students write, model, and evaluate expressions, functions, equations, and inequalities.
Students graph linear equations and interpret the results in solving algebraic problems.
Students solve, graph, or interpret systems of linear equations.
Students connect algebra with other mathematical topics.

text:
CONTENT STANDARD 5. DATA ANALYSIS AND PROBABILITY
Students use data analysis and probability to analyze given situations and the results of experiments.

children.text: Students sort real objects to create graphs.
Students communicate conclusions from a set of data. (Which set has more or less?)
Students collect and classify information to create graphs with pictures and report data in problem-solving situations.
Students communicate conclusions about a set of data using graphs with pictures.
Students perform and record (with tally marks) simple probability experiments.
Students collect, organize, and report data using graphs and Venn diagrams.
Students communicate conclusions about a set of data using graphs and Venn diagrams.
Students perform and record results of simple probability experiments using equally and unequally divided spinners.
Students collect, organize, and compare data using graphs and Venn diagrams.
Students communicate conclusions about a set of data by interpreting information using graphs and Venn diagrams.
Students predict, perform, and record likely results of simple probability experiments.
Students collect, organize, and compare data in graphs, Venn diagrams, tables, and charts.
Students communicate conclusions about a set of data by interpreting information using graphs, Venn diagrams, tables, and charts.
Students predict, perform, and record results of probability experiments.
Students predict all possible outcomes of a given situation or event.
Students systematically collect, organize, and describe/represent categorical data using bar graphs.
Students find and interpret mode for data sets in a problem-solving setting appropriate to grade level. Students communicate their findings.
Students predict and record outcomes of probability experiments or simulations.
Students systematically collect, organize, and describe/represent numeric data using line graphs.
Students, given a scenario, recognize and communicate the likelihood of events using concepts from probability (i.e., impossible, equally likely, certain) appropriate to grade level.
Students systematically collect, organize, describe, and analyze data using histograms.
Students calculate mean, median, mode, and range for data sets and use in real world setting.
Students predict, compare, and report as ratios probable outcomes of experiments or simulations (i.e., impossible, equally likely, certain).
Students systematically collect, organize, describe, analyze, and represent data using tables, charts, diagrams, and graphs.
Students calculate mean, median, mode, and range for data sets and use in a real-world setting appropriate to grade level.
Students predict, compare, and calculate probable outcomes of experiments or simulations.
Students communicate about the likelihood of events using concepts from probability such as impossible, equally likely and certain appropriate to grade level.
Students apply knowledge of mean, median, mode, and range to interpret and evaluate information and data.
Students draw reasonable inferences from statistical data and/or correlation/best fit line to predict outcomes.

Students communicate about the likelihood of events using concepts from probability.
  • sample space
  • evaluate simple probabilities
  • evaluate experimental vs. theoretical
Students determine, collect, organize, and analyze relevant data needed to make conclusions.
